title: Mulino State Airport
text:
Mulino State Airport is a public <a href="airport">airport</a> located at <a href="Mulino%2C%20Oregon">Mulino, Oregon</a>, near the city of <a href="Molalla%2C%20Oregon">Molalla</a>, about 20 <a href="nautical%20mile">nautical mile</a>s (23 <a href="mile">mi</a>, 37 <a href="kilometre">km</a>) south of <a href="Portland%2C%20Oregon">Portland</a> with access from <a href="Interstate%20205%20%28Oregon-Washington%29">Interstate 205</a> via <a href="Oregon%20Route%20213">Oregon Route 213</a>. Also known as Mulino Airport, it was owned by the <a href="Port%20of%20Portland%20%28Oregon%29">Port of Portland</a> from 1988 until it was transferred to the <a href="Oregon%20Department%20of%20Aviation">Oregon Department of Aviation</a> on July 1, 2009. It was previously also known as Portland-Mulino Airport.
This airport is included in the <a href="National%20Plan%20of%20Integrated%20Airport%20Systems">National Plan of Integrated Airport Systems</a> for 2011–2015, which <a href="FAA%20airport%20categories">categorized</a> it as a "<a href="general%20aviation">general aviation</a>" facility. It is home to over 40 light general aviation aircraft (including weekend glider activities) with 34 existing aircraft T-hangars and approximately 25 tie-down spots. Mulino is also home to the Mulino Chapter of the Oregon Pilot Association.
Facilities and aircraft.
Mulino State Airport covers an area of 275 <a href="acre">acre</a>s (111 <a href="hectare">ha</a>) at an <a href="elevation">elevation</a> of 260 feet (79 m) above <a href="mean%20sea%20level">mean sea level</a>. It has one <a href="runway">runway</a> designated 14/32 with an <a href="asphalt">asphalt</a> surface measuring 3,425 by 100 feet (1,044 x 30 m).
For the 12-month period ending April 23, 2009, the airport had 21,300 <a href="general%20aviation">general aviation</a> aircraft operations, an average of 58 per day. At that time there were 47 aircraft based at this airport: 96% single-<a href="aircraft%20engine">engine</a> and 4% <a href="glider%20%28sailplane%29">glider</a>.
